user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
{
	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	if (enable ==  METAL_IRQ_ENABLE) {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
	} else {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_softirq_set_enable:

...
#define METAL_IRQ_ENABLE 1U
...
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments using compiler-specific language extensions were found in the provided code. Specific reasons:
- The function definition (static void metal_softirq_set_enable(...)) uses standard C function syntax and storage-class specifier (static).
- Pointer dereferencing and integer arithmetic (irq -= cntr->irq_base) are standard C constructs.
- The METAL_IRQ_ENABLE macro uses a standard unsigned integer literal suffix (1U), which is standard C.
- The struct metal_irq_controller declaration uses standard C struct syntax and plain types; function-pointer members are standard C.
- The usage of atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], ...) corresponds to the C11 stdatomic.h facility (atomic_store) rather than a compiler-specific keyword; this is a standard language/library feature in C11. No compiler-specific builtins or extensions (for example identifiers beginning with __, __attribute__, __asm, typeof, or other vendor-specific keywords) are present in the supplied fragments.

If the project explicitly targets a C standard older than C11 and the build relies on a compiler-provided atomic extension, that would need separate verification against the compiler documentation. Based solely on the provided code, no explicit compiler language extensions are used, so there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
